Article: Every year like clockwork, new breeds of single-board computers (SBCs) and the latest revisions of our favorite boards hit the market with makers, engineers, and IT professionals alike scrambling to get their hands on them to build projects around the new feature sets they bring. As with any new development technology, this sparks healthy debates among users as to which boards are the best and why some others were not included. This ultimately boils down to âsorting logic,â meaning that they can be sorted in many ways â price points, performance, form factors, user communities, and so forth. Applications also factor into this equation, as task-based SPCs are wide-ranging and handle everything from industrial automation to UAV controllers. As a result, this top 10 roundup focuses on mainstream SBCs that hobbyists, makers, and engineers can use for any number of projects whether theyâre newcomers to the community or 30-year IT veterans. With that said, here are the top 10 mainstream single-board computers currently on the market, or will be for the fall of 2018. Click on image to begin slideshow.  1:  Raspberry Pi 3 Model B+   â $35   (Image credit:  Raspberry Pi  )    The Raspberry Pi has been around for six years now, and every year, the Foundation introduces a new addition to their family. For 2018, the company launched the Raspberry Pi 3 Model B+, an improved version of its predecessor with some notable new features, which includes a 64-bit quad-core Arm Cortex-A53 SoC (@ 1.4 GHz) outfitted with a metal heat sink to handle the increased 200 MHz over the Pi 3.  The board also features dual-band 802.11ac wireless LAN and Bluetooth 4.2, Gigabyte Ethernet (Over USB 2.0), and PoE support (using a separate PoE HAT). Rounding out the Pi 3 Model B+ is an extended 40-pin GPIO header, full-sized HDMI port, four USB 2.0 ports, CSI camera port, DSI display port, and stereo and composite video ports.     Click on image to begin slideshow.Â    2:  UDOO Bolt    â $229  (Image credit:  UDOO  )    The second SBC on the list is unique as it uses AMDâs Ryzen V1000-series SoC over Arm-based hardware, and thereâs a good reason why. The Ryzen Zen architecture combines both a multi-core Zen processor with a Vega GPU, allowing it to drive high-end VR and AI applications. UDOO capitalized on the APU and designed a pair of boards to handle most any project thrown at it.  The midrange BOLT V3 runs an AMD Ryzen dual-core (quad-thread) V1202B APU (with a Vega 3 GPU), while the BOLT V8 packs an AMD Ryzen quad-core (eight-thread) V1605B APU (with a Vega 8 GPU). Thatâs where the differences between the two boards end, as each offers identical hardware, including an SSD card slot, an SATA 3.0 connector, a pair of HDMI ports, and two display ports (via USB Type-C).  Both models also feature two DIMM slots for up to 32 GB of DDR4 RAM, come with 32 GB of on-board flash memory, and are Arduino-Leonardo-compatible, with up to 23 I/Os (seven PWM, one UART, one I2C, one SPI, and 12 analog). The boards do have a couple of drawbacks â there are no wireless capabilities (although you can add Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, or other aftermarket modules), and UDOO is only offering the board through a Kickstarter campaign.
